narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I
Really good insight into the US two party system, including theories around its existence and why it works/doesn't work/how it works.
I learned a lot about how political parties and US political processes/institutions are connected.
I gained valuable insight to the creation of parties in the US and the incredibly influential role they played/play in our political system.

I learned more about the role of political parties, party activists, and other interest groups in campaigning and elections, especially with regard to the presidency and Congress. Additionally, I was able to compare various theories for the same electoral outcomes.
I learned how to understand American political parties in theory and practice. I also gained a greater understanding of spatial models.
Understanding of the roles of political parties in elections, policy making, and history
I gained a better understanding of the role of political parties in American government.
Learned a lot about the history of the political parties and what their role in American society was and is. We also learned a lot about the theory of political parties.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures were very bland and not conducive to creating an environment for engaged students. I think this was likely exacerbated by the virtual setting.

I enjoyed the material, but the lectures online sometimes made me feel isolated from the other students. My section was also really small, so discussion was difficult to have. I did enjoy the professor's lectures and his attitude about the class.

Strengths - interesting content, but section was where I really felt like I engaged with the content. Also, I took this class during the 2020 election which was really interesting.

Weaknesses - some of the readings seemed kinda redundant/useless - I felt that reading the selections that were discussed in section was important, but not the entire set of readings.

Strengths of the course was the purpose fo the course. I think it is very important that people understand the role of parties.

Weakness of the course was the emphasis on readings. We spent a lot of time in section and exams looking at very dense long readings. I found myself getting more confused by the authors and losing track of the concept we were actually talking about. Also we are expected to complete 6-9 of these dense readings a week and be able to compare them to each other. I thought this was far too many to keep straight in my head .

Strengths: the clear instructions throughout the course and the professors willingness to answer questions and ensure that students truly understood the concepts. Additionally, it was helpful that the professor provided all the powerpoint presentations and readings directly on Canvas. Weaknesses: due to the online lecture format, the class engagement during lecture was sometimes low.

Strengths: Great discussion sections, manageable reading load, lectures were engaging

Weaknesses: Exam formatting
A strength was the level of interaction between the professor and students during lecture. I also appreciated how the professor answered questions after the lecture.
This was an incredible class. The readings were amazing and it is worth taking this class for the readings alone.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual was incredibly difficult for learning.
Lectures were hard to get through with feeling disconnected. However, the professor made sure we all understood the topic before moving on, so that was really helpful and nice.
I thought Professor Henderson did a great job making the class compatible with pandemic virtual learning.
The practices that were most successful: putting all course material, including lecture presentations and lecture recordings, on Canvas.
I thought the live virtual lectures were very effective. I appreciated that the lectures were recorded so that I could go back and review them.
The availability of office hours and discussion sections were helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Especially if you enjoy American politics and want to understand the political system we use.
I would recommend this course - it is really interesting, and Professor Henderson is a good lecturer. As a non polisci major, I feel like I was not behind the curve or anything

Perhaps. If they were interested in the foundations of politics this would be a great class. However, I would warn them of the confusing readings and the amount of reading they would be expected to do.
Yes, I would strongly recommend this course to any student that is looking for a solid foundation to electoral politics in the United States, and the role of political parties and party activists.
Yes I would recommend this course. It was very interesting and a great course for gaining a deeper understanding of American politics.
Yes. Great course for Political Science majors and non- Political Science majors
I would recommend this course because it equips students with a better understanding of the role of political parties in American government.
YES. I didnt know whether or not to take this class, but I can say that it MADE MY YEAR. I seriously cannot recommend this class highly enough.
